pending_diagnosis: DIAGNOSIS: Acute Intermittent Porphyria (AIP) THE SMOKING GUN: On deeper review of her recent history (obtained from her partner), she reported starting a new herbal supplement for "stress relief" three weeks ago. Further forensic testing of the supplement's ingredients revealed it contained significant quantities of St. John's Wort, a potent inducer of hepatic CYP450 enzymes. This induction, combined with physiological stress, precipitated the acute attack. PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: AIP is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a deficiency in hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMBS), leading to the accumulation of neurotoxic porphyrin precursors: delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) and porphobilinogen (PBG). These precursors are highly soluble and cross the blood-brain barrier. The clinical syndrome is characterized by the "3 Ps": Pain (severe abdominal), Psychosis, and Polyneuropathy (often motor-dominant, ascending). The severe hypertension and tachycardia reflect sympathetic overdrive due to autonomic neuropathy. The profound hyponatremia (Na 117 mEq/L) is classic and typically results from Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH), which PBG is thought to trigger centrally. Treatment involves high-dose dextrose (to suppress heme synthesis) and IV administration of hemin (heme arginate) to repress the upstream enzyme (ALA synthase).
